messages.text: Sooo, how do we proceed? I think we could either a) continue to fix the long tail of bugs we're seeing on crash reporting, or b) say this is good enough for now and open things up for new feature merges. I'm indifferent :slightly_smiling_face: But it does seem that we still have a number of crash reports that might be easy to fix, so that if we did 1-2 more releases in the a) spirit we could _really_ get our crash report count down?

elements.text: Sooo, how do we proceed? I think we could either a) continue to fix the long tail of bugs we're seeing on crash reporting, or b) say this is good enough for now and open things up for new feature merges. I'm indifferent
But it does seem that we still have a number of crash reports that might be easy to fix, so that if we did 1-2 more releases in the a) spirit we could
really
get our crash report count down?

messages.text: So I think that means we need to accept docs with NULL in it in terms of doc content. Question now is just whether we then declare an error at the CSTParser level? And show a diagnostic info for it? And in particular don't try to resolve `include` in these files. OR we limit this even more and _just_ don't use these strings if they appear in `include` statements... Not sure what the best thing is.

elements.text: So I think that means we need to accept docs with NULL in it in terms of doc content. Question now is just whether we then declare an error at the CSTParser level? And show a diagnostic info for it? And in particular don't try to resolve
include
in these files. OR we limit this even more and
just
don't use these strings if they appear in
include
statements... Not sure what the best thing is.

messages.text: So on the NULL strings thing I think we need to be guided by Meta.parse, e.g. it accepts NULLS (I think). That would point to special handling at the point of trying to interpret the include call right?

elements.text: So on the NULL strings thing I think we need to be guided by Meta.parse, e.g. it accepts NULLS (I think). That would point to special handling at the point of trying to interpret the include call right?

messages.text: It seems we could either do an explicit check or catch the errors

elements.text: It seems we could either do an explicit check or catch the errors

messages.text:
Yes, I just tried
```julia> Meta.parse("\"foo\0bar\"")
"foo\0bar"```

elements.text: Yes, I just tried

julia> Meta.parse("\"foo\0bar\"")
"foo\0bar"

messages.text: So it definitely seems to accept NULLs, so yep, we just need to check this when trynig to follow includes. I always like explicit checks better than catching errors, I think :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: So it definitely seems to accept NULLs, so yep, we just need to check this when trynig to follow includes. I always like explicit checks better than catching errors, I think

messages.text: I'm starting to wonder whether we should run the tests in all packages that we ship as part of the azure pipeline build, at least on `master`....

elements.text: I'm starting to wonder whether we should run the tests in all packages that we ship as part of the azure pipeline build, at least on
master

messages.text: We're shipping a lot of packages now, and we're updating them without much careful consideration what changed in them... And we don't really know whether they all have CI configured to for example run on all platforms and Julia versions that we want to make sure things work on.

elements.text: We're shipping a lot of packages now, and we're updating them without much careful consideration what changed in them... And we don't really know whether they all have CI configured to for example run on all platforms and Julia versions that we want to make sure things work on.

messages.text: So maybe we should just run all tests in all packages that we ship as part of our CI? Right now we only run the CI in the packages that we develop ourselves...

elements.text: So maybe we should just run all tests in all packages that we ship as part of our CI? Right now we only run the CI in the packages that we develop ourselves...

messages.text: <@U6BNE7LTZ> is <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/blob/master/src/scripts/updateDeps.ts#L31> still the best way to do things? I think you reorganized what the "truth" is for all of this? Or should we just ignore for now because we are going to remove the grammar from our extension in any case as soon as it ships in the VS Code core?

elements.text: is

still the best way to do things? I think you reorganized what the "truth" is for all of this? Or should we just ignore for now because we are going to remove the grammar from our extension in any case as soon as it ships in the VS Code core?

• <https://github.com/julia-vscode/LanguageServer.jl/pull/899> (needs review)
